displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: What do you mean I won’t be - Healthcare Professional: D____ doesn’t start um - Doctor: Wait, he doesn’t have Healthcare Professional: Yeah, I was going to put a sticker up there. D____ doesn’t start I.V.’s; she can only draw blood. Patient: No? Family Member: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that.

Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later. Doctor: Okay, we’re having a good discussion. They were afraid I was gonna give them a quiz at the end of it but I think we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Alright, I promise not to, no, I probably shouldn’t promise I won’t interrupt again. Doctor: Of course you won’t. Family Member: So, if it’s bone only after the scans, Doctor: Yeah Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then you and I just have to pick a day when you wanna start chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, some of it is, you can look at a calendar. The end of the year is coming. You know, Christmas, New Year’s, Thanksgiving. You know, what day, eh, do you wanna plan it out. ‘Cuz once we get started, it’s gonna be every three weeks. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? You’re gonna come in two weeks which would be the twenty-first. You could theoretically get your first chemo then. You may also say, “Uh, no, let’s wait two more weeks.” Patient: Until the third of January or something.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like- Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go.

Patient: Okay. I, now, now, now look Doc G_. I go’d up, I go there by W__. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right down F__ and T__ by W___. So, that’s where be at. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: But, I said, I just moved right across from ___ in M___. So, when I go over there, that’s why I, I, you know what I’m sayin’. Some girlfriends of mine; they had to go to the store. And, when I went to the store, I had to run in the alley, man. I couldn’t make it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. So, I will, um, I’ll give you a prescription for a medication called “Lomotil” which helps with the diarrhea. Patient: And I, and I Doctor: I am not going to give you the chemo today. I think we should take a break for a couple of weeks. Patient: You ain’t gonna give it to me? Doctor: No. Because, let this diarrhea settle down. The last thing we want is for the chemo to aggravate it even more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So, we’ll give it a couple of weeks for you to heal up, get over this. Then, we will get back on the chemotherapy. Okay?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I might need pictures if we can’t your catheter is out. So what’s the problem there? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So most of that really is just plumbing. Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: And so those are the cells that over time, as I said over an average of three to five years end up coming back, or returning and that’s what’s called - Family Member: Despite the hormone therapy. Doctor: Despite the hormone therapy. Family Member: So you can’t like change it, modify it, up it, lower it or whatever? Doctor: Correct. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s been tried; even the addition of chemotherapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yet it prolongs the recurrence, but it still doesn’t prevent the recurrence or prevent it recurring. Healthcare Professional: But then there’s therapies that happen. Doctor: Right. That’s one of the last options Healthcare Professional: Yeah, yeah, there are other therapies for when that happens.

Healthcare Professional: You want to go - Well maybe you should go down there and then you can come back up and get your treatment. Doctor: Yeah, maybe you can go, yeah, okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, that way you don’t miss your appointment down there. Doctor: Yeah that makes sense, while they’re preparing the treatment. Family Member: Right. Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles)

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You are. Okay. No that’s critical information that I need to know (laughs) Family Member 2: He doesn’t like the trips. Doctor: I know, know. Patient: Yeah, that’s the thing. Family Member 2: It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s you know, now it’s only like every three weeks so… Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. Patient: It’s not quite that. It’s not so bad. Doctor: It’s much less so. Family Member: And there’s no affiliation obviously in Toledo that… Doctor: No. Not – well especially for these studies. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We are under such strict regulations that we can’t even do it in our own satellite in F____.

Patient: Yeah. That does help. Family Member 1: So, okay. Family Member 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take? Family Member 1: Like 10? Doctor: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter. Family Member 2: Mhmm. Doctor: That it's a pretty non toxic agent. So I think you could try one and if it really doesn't work in a half an hour, then take another pill. Family Member 2: Because I know sometimes I take 10 milligrams, and my doctor told me only five to 10. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member 2: So I’ll take one or two. So for him, he could do the same? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member 2: Okay.

Patient: Hm, I did not know that. Doctor: Yes and it’s one drug called Taxotere and it’s given through the IV so usually either arm… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …once over one hour every three weeks. Patient: Hm, okay. Doctor: Okay? We do have a study coming up doing that, plus vitamin C high dose. Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even at one or two scans are unlikely to be positive. Patient: Right. Doctor: I’m not having a lot of good luck telling you what’s average. Family Member: He seems to be the Patient: But even you know the PSA values I think you mentioned at one of the previous meetings you know in of itself the value itself wouldn’t have – my – the only thing was the trending and I get that part of it because you had mentioned you’ve seen it in points to where you know some people would be an eleven, you know that was a signal on that one, but for it to be a three and a half or something like that one you know the number alone you know it didn’t… Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah I’ve showed your case in a conference and everybody was like oh my God. Family Member: Um hum. lucky Patient: When do I meet him? Doctor: Not for a long time. Patient: Ladies and gentlemen your test subject. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay I’m gonna talk to J____ about getting these arrangements –

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. Especially, uh, you know we wouldn’t let you go if you weren’t feeling great. And I need to ask, the thing to ask M___, is you know if it gets too late, you know, could you stay a second night if you wanted to. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know? So if you’re pooped out, you just go home the next day. So we could ask her about that. Patient: I mean, I mean there are places I could go. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I got moved to the big house last week. Doctor: Oh. Patient: I don’t think I have the pictures any more. Doctor: And how do you feel about it? Patient: I was living like a king over there. You know? Patient: You go, you go in this room, and I would call that I mean if I was rich it would be a kids homework room It’s fourteen by maybe twenty.
